conversation.content: [nervioso] Eh, Danny, sé que han pasado, [tembloroso], tres años desde que hablamos pero o sea, el abogado de papá me mandó a, [quebrándose], buscarte porque hay algo que, bueno, necesitas saber sobre su testamento.
[amargo] Pues, la hermana pródiga aparece en mi, eh, taller cubierto de grasa y aceite solo para traer más decepciones, quiero decir.

[temblando] Te dejó 50.000 dólares pero, em, hay una condición y sé que vas a, [frustrado], odiar esto pero solo es accesible si, bueno, [voz quebrada], lo usas para educación a través de tus beneficios militares. [suspira profundamente]

[atónito] Hasta desde la tumba intenta, [enfadado], controlar mi vida y hacerme sentir que, [más bajo], arreglar calderas durante 20 años no era, [amargo], suficientemente bueno para su precioso apellido familiar.
[a la defensiva] Danny, o sea, no se trata de eso y, eh, sabes que solo quería que tuvieras, [más suave], opciones más allá de arrastrarte por los sótanos de la gente.
[voz elevada] ¿Opciones? Pues, tenía opciones cuando volví de Afganistán pero, em, nadie pensó que el tío que podía, [sarcástico], desactivar IEDs podría saber lo que quería, ¿sabes?

[suplicando] Soy yo el que procesa estos beneficios todos los días y, eh, veo a veteranos transformar sus vidas y quiero decir, [emocionado], siempre fuiste el más listo de nosotros así que, [quebrándose], ¿por qué no te permites tener esto, pues?
[callado] Em, estoy cansado. [pausa larga]
Me enseñaste a, [melancólico], leer cuando mamá estaba demasiado enferma para levantarse de la cama, ¿recuerdas?
[vacilante] Pues, no lo hagas.

Eh, solías dibujar esos planos elaborados de, [sonriendo con tristeza], máquinas imposibles y me decías que un día, [con voz entrecortada], construirías algo que cambiaría el mundo y o sea, [llorando], todavía podrías Danny. [sollozos]
[a la defensiva] Esos eran solo, bueno, sueños estúpidos de crío antes de aprender lo que el mundo, eh, realmente necesitaba de gente como yo, ¿sabes?

[firme] Pues, lo que el mundo necesita es que dejes de, [apasionado], castigarte por sobrevivir cuando Martínez y Thompson no lo hicieron y, em, que vivas la vida que ellos, [feroz], querrían que vivieras, quiero decir.
Sarah, no tienes ni idea de lo que, [temblando], es cargar con ese peso cada maldito, [tenso], día de tu vida. [se quiebra la voz]
[suave] No, no la tengo pero sé lo que es, [lloroso], ver a mi hermano desaparecer en su dolor.
[derrumbándose] Tengo miedo de que si, bueno, vuelvo a estudiar e intento ser algo más, eh, los olvidaré y el sacrificio que, [sollozando], hicieron no significará nada, ¿sabes? [llorando]
Murieron protegiendo algo en lo que creían que era la oportunidad para gente como nosotros de, [fuerte], volver a casa y construir vidas mejores.
[callado] Pues, papá nunca me dijo que estaba orgulloso de mi servicio pero, em, quizá este dinero es su forma de, [dándose cuenta], decir que se equivocó conmigo, ¿sabes?
[cálido] O sea, guardaba todas las fotos que enviaste desde allí en el cajón de su escritorio y, bueno, me dijo una vez que eras, [tierno], el más valiente de todos nosotros.
[decidido] Si hago esto, si cojo el dinero y, [esperanzado], vuelvo a estudiar, ¿me ayudarás con el, [vulnerable], papeleo y toda esa pesadilla burocrática? [ríe suavemente]

original_conversation.content: [nervous] Um, Danny, I know it's been, [shaky], three years since we've talked but I mean, Dad's lawyer sent me to, [breaking], find you because there's something you, well, need to know about his will.
[bitter] Well, the prodigal sister shows up at my, uh, workshop covered in grease and oil just to deliver more disappointment, I mean.

[trembling] He left you fifty thousand dollars but, um, there's a catch and I know you're going to, [frustrated], hate this but it's only accessible if you, well, [voice cracking], use it for education through your GI benefits. [sighs heavily]
[stunned] Even from the grave he's trying to, [angry], control my life and make me feel like, [quieter], fixing furnaces for twenty years wasn't, [bitter], good enough for his precious family name.
[defensive] Danny, I mean, that's not what this is about and, um, you know he just wanted you to have, [softer], options beyond crawling through people's basements.
[raised voice] Options? Well, I had options when I came back from Afghanistan but, um, nobody thought the guy who could, [sarcastic], disarm IEDs might actually know what he wanted, you know?

[pleading] I'm the one who processes these benefits every day and, um, I see veterans transform their lives and I mean, [emotional], you were always the smartest one of us so, [breaking], why won't you just let yourself have this, well?
[quiet] Um, I'm tired. [long pause]
You taught me how to, [wistful], read when Mom was too sick to get out of bed remember?
[wavering] Well, don't.

Um, you used to draw these elaborate blueprints for, [smiling sadly], impossible machines and tell me that one day you'd, [choking up], build something that would change the world and I mean, [crying], you still could Danny. [sniffles]
[defensive] Those were just, well, stupid kid dreams before I learned what the world, uh, actually needed from people like me, you know.

[firm] Well, what the world needs is for you to stop, [passionate], punishing yourself for surviving when Martinez and Thompson didn't and, um, actually live the life they'd, [fierce], want you to live, I mean.
Sarah, you have no idea what, [shaking], it's like to carry that weight every single, [strained], day of your life. [voice breaks]
[gentle] No, I don't but I know what it's like to, [tearful], watch my brother disappear into his grief.
[breaking down] I'm scared that if I, well, go back to school and try to be something more, um, I'll forget them and the sacrifice they, [sobbing], made will mean nothing, you know? [crying]
They died protecting something they believed in which was the chance for people like us to, [strong], come home and build better lives.
[quiet] Well, Dad never told me he was proud of my service but, um, maybe this money is his way of, [realizing], saying he was wrong about me, you know?
[warm] I mean, he kept every photo you sent from overseas in his desk drawer and, well, he told me once that you were, [tender], the bravest of all of us.
[resolved] If I do this, if I take the money and, [hopeful], go back to school, will you help me through the, [vulnerable], paperwork and all that bureaucratic nightmare? [softly laughs]

scenario: A GI Bill coordinator visits an oil burner technician who is her estranged brother, a veteran who never used his educational benefits, to tell him their father left him money specifically for going back to school.
